central_thesis: This publication, a journal for the Temple of Set community, primarily explores the philosophy and practical application of Setian magical development, focusing on individual self-deification (Xeper), the understanding and manifestation of Neteru (primal principles), and the significance of discovering one's true magical name. It also provides biographical insights into prominent Setian figures and addresses internal community discussions and operational announcements.

structure_content.summary: This section details Magistra Lilith Sinclair's spiritual and magical journey from a Catholic upbringing to atheism, then to the Church of Satan where she achieved the degree of Priestess III°, and finally to the Temple of Set as Magistra Templi IV°. It highlights her fascination with the 'Dark Side,' her leadership of the Lilith Grotto, public engagement as the 'Occult Superstar of the East Coast,' and her process of discovering her magical name 'Lilith' and ritual name 'Uræus,' emphasizing the deeply personal nature of magical identity within the Setian tradition.

This article discusses varying 'Set-Experiences,' particularly the phenomenon of 'gut-wrenching fear' reported by some Setians who began their magical path during the 'Age of Satan' or 'Set-HarWer period.' The author contrasts this with their own experience, which began in the 'true Æon of Set' and involved accepting 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night' literally and viewing Set as a friend. It suggests that fear may stem from exposure to HarWer (the 'opposite Self') and emphasizes that true Xeper and the discovery of one's magical name are stages achieved through consistent effort, study, and often with mentorship.

A brief announcement detailing an upcoming total solar eclipse on February 26th, visible in specific regions of the US and Canada. It includes a cautionary note on the dangers of direct viewing and recommends pin-hole projection as the only safe method, also mentioning the availability of an eclipse-viewing kit.

This piece explores the nature of understanding and interpretation, asserting that 'reality = actuality = force of will.' The author argues that interpreting written ideas (objective) requires using one's own mind as a subjective model to grasp another's perspective, acknowledging that abstract concepts inherently lose some clarity when translated into language.

This article advocates for viewing Neters as 'primal principles' (Platonic Forms) rather than merely sentient entities. It proposes three ways Neters gain 'life': ancient personification, collective magical energy, or individual subconscious projection, or a synthesis thereof. The author stresses that an Adept's affinity with a Neter is secondary to 'what an Adept does with it,' likening magical power to the stature of the practitioner. It further elucidates that the 'true magical name' is not chosen but discovered, serving as a catalyst for the fusion of the 'macrocosmic Neter' and the 'microcosmic spark,' leading to self-deification.

This section is a request from Michael A. Aquino V° for financial assistance for Priestess Linda Thomas, who faces major surgery for carcinoma but lacks insurance coverage. A raffle for a valuable book, John Dryden's 'All For Love,' is announced, with proceeds directed to her medical expenses, and community updates on her progress are promised.

key_concepts.definition: A philosophy and magical practice, as propagated by the Temple of Set, focused on the individual's self-deification and the development of the Black Adept, often contrasting with traditional Satanism through its unique emphasis on Xeper and the Neteru.

The core Setian principle of 'self-creation' or 'becoming,' representing the ongoing process of individual magical development and evolution towards godhood. It requires intellectual rigor, magical study, and strengthening of the will.

A name not chosen but discovered by a magician, expressing their essential nature. It acts as a profound link or catalyst for the fusion of the individual's microcosmic spark with a macrocosmic Neter, a crucial step towards self-deification.

Primal principles or archetypal Forms (akin to Platonic Forms) that can manifest as sentient entities. Their 'life' can arise from ancient personification, collective magical energy, individual subconscious projection, or a combination of these. An Adept's interaction and 'stature' determine the outcome of working with a Neter.

A philosophical orientation within magical practice emphasizing self-accomplishment, individual power, and personal advancement, distinct from the 'White Side' which is associated with altruistic goals.

Described as the 'opposite Self,' an entity or principle whose presence during certain magical periods (e.g., 'Age of Satan' or 'Set-HarWer period') is associated with causing confusion and fear among practitioners.
A high initiatory degree within the Temple of Set, signifying advanced magical attainment, personal evolution, and leadership, exemplified by Magistra Lilith Sinclair.

practical_system.description: The text outlines a system of personal magical development centered on the principle of Xeper (self-creation) within the Setian tradition. This is achieved through intellectual rigor, consistent magical study, hard work, and strengthening the will. A core operative mechanism involves the discovery (not invention) of one's 'true magical name,' which is seen as expressing the magician's essential nature. This name then functions as a catalyst for a profound fusion between the individual's 'microcosmic spark' and a 'macrocosmic Neter' (primal principle), leading to an advanced state of self-deification or 'godhood.' The efficacy of working with Neters depends on the Adept's 'stature' and what they actively *do* with their affinity.
tools: The Book of Coming Forth by Night (as foundational text and literal word of Set)
True magical name (as a link/catalyst for Neter fusion)
rituals: Workings using a ritual name (e.g., Uræus to evoke the Cobra goddess)
Initiatory tests for advancement through degrees (e.g., Witch II°, Priestess III°)

relevant_quotes.text: She walks in beauty, because she is beauty dark, radiant, queenly, vital - a goddess!
It was as though LaVey had known her thoughts while writing his book.
Her ritual name, which she uses only in workings when she wants to evoke the Cobra goddess with whom she identifies, is Uræus, the Serpent One.
Ultimately she desires to be powerful, proficient, highly-evolved, skilled sorceress that she can - 'to dare the Black Magic' and succeed.

I think that Setians should be be able to equate the Neters with the Platonic Forms [if they don't understand that, they should read Plato] and to view them as primal principles rather than as sentient entities, even though some of them may fall into that category as well.
The important thing is not whether or not such a relationship or affinity exists, but what an Adept does with it.

A true magical name is not a matter of choice; it is something which comes to the magician. No true magical name is created by the magician, looking at it in one sense. Rather he discovers the name which expresses something which he recognizes as his essential nature.

When that fusion is at last complete - when the heart of the magician has given him full Understanding of his Name, so that he has become his Name - then, in truth, a god shall walk the Earth, imperishable.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of 'The Scroll of Set' is highly relevant for understanding the early philosophical development and community dynamics of the Temple of Set. It distinguishes Setianism from its Church of Satan origins by emphasizing the internal, individualistic path of Xeper and the unique understanding of Neteru. The discussions on 'Set-Experiences' and the nature of magical names provide valuable insights into the practical and theoretical concerns of early Setian practitioners. It serves as a primary source for scholars of modern Western esotericism, Left-Hand Path traditions, and the institutional history of the Temple of Set.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience was active members and aspirants of the Temple of Set in 1979, particularly those engaged with the 'Scroll of Set' journal. It catered to individuals seeking guidance on personal magical development, understanding Setian philosophy, and staying informed about community affairs. Additionally, it is a crucial document for researchers and historians studying contemporary occult movements and the evolution of Setian thought.
